# Discord Chat Analysis for ðŸ’»â”‚developers

## 1. Summary
The discussion primarily focused on technical aspects of vehicle implementation in the platform. Ashxn shared that they're pivoting to a single armature with bones for vehicle components (wheels, doors, lights, trunk) to achieve better rendering efficiency with a single draw call. This approach differs from the previous implementation that used empties in v1. TheMattEmpire discussed VRM optimization techniques for Blender, specifically how combining multiple mesh blendshapes into one can reduce file size. Ashxn confirmed that vehicle customization is fully possible using the engine's existing capabilities, mentioning specific functions like `skinnedmesh.getBone(name)` for manipulating bone transforms and physics functions for raycasting suspension and wheel forces. Ashxn also noted that when they release their car collection to Hyper holders, the core application will be open-sourced to allow for custom car skins.

## 2. FAQ
Q: Is there a max file size/video length for videos? (asked by vincentskele) A: It's a setting per world (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Can you show what meshes etc look in blender? (asked by vox) A: Unanswered
Q: Will it be a bit similar like preping cars for v1? (asked by vox) A: We're pivoting to a single armature with bones instead of empties. Similar but different. (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Is it possible to start making our own [cars] this way? (asked by ~/drdoge.eth) A: 10000% possible. Everything is in the engine with functions for bone transforms and physics. (answered by Ashxn)

## 3. Help Interactions

# Discord Chat Analysis

## 1. Summary
The chat primarily focused on technical discussions around Hyperfy platform capabilities and deployment options. Key topics included embedding Hyperfy worlds in Next.js applications, with clarification that while Next.js is primarily for 2D websites, Hyperfy worlds could be embedded via iframes or by pointing subdomains to hyperworld.host. There was discussion about the limitations of deploying on Vercel due to Hyperfy's multiplayer component requiring a server rather than serverless architecture. Users explored potential use cases beyond social/gaming applications, particularly highlighting 3D environment portfolios for businesses and artists as a promising market. Other technical points included a mention of React Native becoming viable for a hypothetical Hyperfy mobile app, and a GitHub repository for creating avatars for crypto projects. There was also brief discussion about Hyperfy's token economics, with clarification on market cap versus fully diluted valuation.

## 2. FAQ
Q: Can anyone clarify the actual market cap for Hyper, is it currently 6.2 or 2.7? (asked by Greguar) A: Fully diluted 6.2, market cap takes into account circulating supply (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Do you think it's possible to spin a world on a next.js vercel web app? (asked by Sceth iii) A: Nextjs is specific to building 2D websites, you could embed your world in a nextjs app with an iframe though (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Have you guys tried reaching out to zssbecker? (asked by rando1337) A: Unanswered

## 3. Help Interactions
Helper: Ashxn | Helpee: Sceth iii | Context: Deploying Hyperfy worlds with Next.js | Resolution: Suggested using hyperworld.host and either embedding via iframe or pointing a subdomain to hyperworld
Helper: peezy | Helpee: Sceth iii | Context: Limitations of Vercel for Hyperfy deployment | Resolution: Explained that Hyperfy's multiplayer component requires a server while Vercel focuses on serverless applications
Helper: maximus | Helpee: Sceth iii | Context: Use cases for 3D environment portfolios | Resolution: Shared experience building interactive elements with web view integration for booking meetings

## 4. Action Items
